title: Jerusalem Shooting: 5 Dead, 12 Injured in Attack at Bus Stop
snippets: Paramedics said at least five people were killed in a shooting attack in Jerusalem after two attackers opened fire at a bus stop at a busy intersection in north Jerusalem.
Israeli police say two gunmen were killed after the attack, which was one of the deadliest in the city in years.
Paramedics say at least 12 people are injured in the morning attack with six in "serious condition".
Israeli authorities identified the two gunmen, who were killed at the scene, as Palestinians from the West Bank.
The Israeli police described the shooting as a terrorist attack and said that the perpetrators had been killed at the scene.

JERUSALEM (AP) — Palestinian attackers opened fire at a bus stop at during the morning rush hour in Jerusalem on Monday, killing six people and wounding another 12, according to Israeli officials. An Israeli soldier and civilians who were at the scene shot and killed the two attackers, said police,
titles: Shooting attack at Jerusalem bus stop kills at least 5
Six killed by Palestinian gunmen at Jerusalem bus stop
Shooting in occupied East Jerusalem kills six, Israeli authorities say
Gunmen kill 6 in shooting attack at Jerusalem bus stop, police say
Gunmen Attack Bus Stop in Jerusalem, Killing at Least 6
Palestinian gunmen kill 6 people in attack on Jerusalem bus stop
summary: In Jerusalem, a shooting at a bus stop by two Palestinian attackers from the West Bank resulted in at least five deaths and 12 injuries, with six in serious condition. The incident, occurring during the morning rush hour, is among the deadliest in the city in recent years. Israeli police and civilians at the scene responded, killing the two gunmen. Authorities are treating the event as a terrorist attack.

title: Alcaraz Wins Second US Open, Regains World No. 1 Ranking
snippets: Carlos Alcaraz reasserted his superiority over Jannik Sinner with a 6-2, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4 win Sunday in the US Open final -- the third Grand Slam tournament in a row in which these rivals met to decide a champion -- for his second title at Flushing Meadows.

summary: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner in four sets (6-2, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4) to win his second US Open title and his sixth Grand Slam. This victory in New York also returned Alcaraz to the world number one ranking. The final, which marked the third consecutive Grand Slam final between Alcaraz and Sinner, experienced delays due to heightened security measures.

title: Court Upholds $83.3M Defamation Judgment Against Trump
snippets: A federal appeals court has upheld the $83.3 million judgment imposed on President Trump for defaming former magazine columnist E. Jean Carroll in 2019.
Carroll has accused Trump of defaming her in statements denying her accusation that he raped her decades earlier in a New York City department store.

Federal appeals court upholds defamation judgment against Trump, rejecting the administration’s argument that he’s protected by supreme court immunity ruling

Intent on vindication after spending four months in prison last year, Peter Navarro asked a federal appeals court on
The judgment has now ballooned to more than $89 million with interest.

summary: A federal appeals court upheld an $83.3 million judgment against former President Trump for defaming E. Jean Carroll, who accused him of rape. The court rejected Trump's immunity claim. With interest, the judgment exceeds $89 million.

title: Erin Patterson Gets Life for Murdering 3 Relatives with Poisonous Mushrooms
snippets: Australian mother Erin Patterson has been sentenced to a minimum of 33 years in prison for murdering three of her former
The judge handed out a non-parole period of 33 years to Erin Patterson for poisoning four of her estranged husband's relatives with death cap mushrooms.
Erin Patterson was convicted of killing three relatives with a lunch laced with death cap mushrooms. The judge called her actions “an enormous betrayal of trust.”
Triple murderer sentenced in Victorian supreme court after killing relatives with a beef wellington lunch laced with death cap mushrooms
Erin Patterson was convicted in July of murdering Don and Gail Patterson and Gail’s sister, Heather Wilkinson, with a lunch of foraged death cap mushrooms.

A Victorian supreme court judge has sentenced Erin Patterson to life imprisonment with a non-parole period of 33 years. A jury had previously found Patterson guilty of three counts of murder and one count of attempted murder by serving beef wellingtons laced with deadly death cap mushrooms. She h

Erin Patterson has been sentenced to life in prison with a non-parole period of 33 years after murdering three people and attempting to murder a fourth with a lunch laced with death cap mushrooms. Patterson, 50, was found guilty of murdering Don and Gail Patterson – the parents of her estranged h
titles: Australia mushroom murderer sentenced to life imprisonment

Watch in full: Erin Patterson sentenced to life in prison for Australian mushroom murders – video
Erin Patterson: Australia's mushroom murderer sentenced to life in prison – video
summary: Erin Patterson was sentenced to life in prison with a minimum non-parole period of 33 years by an Australian court for murdering three of her estranged husband's relatives and attempting to murder a fourth by serving them a meal containing death cap mushrooms. The judge noted Patterson showed no remorse for her actions, which were described as a significant betrayal of trust.

title: Nepal Protests: 19 Dead as Citizens Rally Against Corruption, Social Media Ban
snippets: Young protesters are demanding the government lift its social media ban and tackle corruption.
A Kathmandu District Administration Office spokesperson says police used water cannon, batons and rubber bullets.
Protesters are agitating against corruption and a ban on major social media platforms.

Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant

At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.

The government has fa
Demonstrators stormed the Parliament complex days after the government banned most social media platforms. At least 200 people were injured, local news media reported.
titles: At least 19 dead in Nepal after Gen Z protests at corruption and social media ban
At least 19 killed in Nepal protests over social media ban, corruption
Nepal Gen Z protests amid social media ban, clashes kill 19: All to know
At least 19 killed in ‘gen Z’ protests against Nepal’s social media ban
At Least 12 Are Killed in Nepal in Protests Over Social Media Ban
summary: In Nepal, protests erupted against government corruption and the ban of major social media platforms, including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and X. Demonstrators, demanding the lifting of the ban and addressing corruption, clashed with police who used water cannons, batons, and rubber bullets. The unrest led to at least 19 deaths and over 200 injuries. Protesters also stormed the Parliament complex, highlighting widespread frustration with nepotism and governance issues.

While this specific disagreement has been resolved, Manchester City still faces charges related to breaching other financial regulations, with the outcome of those charges still pending.

title: Missing Man Since 2021 Killed by NZ Police, Children Found Safe
snippets: Tom Phillips disappeared with his three children in 2021 after losing a custody battle.

Phillips, who has been on the run with his children for four years, was shot by police after officers came under fire while investigating burglary in Piopio, authorities said

Tom Phillips went missing with his children in 2021, sparking a New Zealand search. His children were found unharmed.

summary: Tom Phillips, missing since 2021 with his three children after a custody battle, was shot dead by New Zealand police during a burglary investigation in Piopio. He fired at officers, prompting the response. The children were found safe. This incident marks the end of a four-year search for Phillips, who had been hiding in New Zealand's wilderness.

title: Lamar Jackson Regrets Shoving Fan After Helmet Slap Incident
snippets: During Sunday night's 41-40 loss to the Buffalo Bills in the season opener, Baltimore Ravens quarterback Lamar Jackson shoved a fan who slapped Jackson on the helmet. "I just let my emotions get the best of me," Jackson later told reporters.
DeAndre Hopkins also got slapped on the helmet by the same fan just before Jackson did
Watch as a Bills fan hits DeAndre Hopkins and Lamar Jackson as they celebrate their touchdown, and the Ravens’ QB responds with a shove of his own in the stands.
titles: Jackson shoves fan in retaliation in Ravens' loss
Lamar Jackson shoves Bills fan in retaliation for getting slapped on helmet following Ravens TD in Buffalo
Bills fan, Ravens’ Jackson trade shoves after Hopkins TD
summary: During the season opener against the Buffalo Bills, Baltimore Ravens quarterback Lamar Jackson and teammate DeAndre Hopkins were slapped on the helmet by a fan while celebrating a touchdown. Jackson responded by shoving the fan. Jackson later expressed regret, stating his emotions got the best of him.

title: SpaceX Buys EchoStar Spectrum for $17B, Boosts Mobile with Starlink
snippets: The deal will allow Boost Mobile subscribers to access direct-to-cell service from SpaceX’s Starlink.

Dish parent company EchoStar is selling wireless spectrum licenses to SpaceX for around $17 billion, the companies announced on Monday. SpaceX says it will use the spectrum to create the “next generation” of Starlink’s cellular satellite service, which customers of the EchoStar-owned Boost Mobile wi
EchoStar’s stock soars further into record territory after a $17 billion deal to sell spectrum to Elon Musk’s SpaceX.
titles: SpaceX Purchasing Wireless Spectrum Licenses From EchoStar For $17 Billion
EchoStar offloads satellite spectrum to SpaceX for $17 billion
SpaceX deal sends EchoStar’s stock soaring. Why Musk is buying $17 billion in wireless spectrum.
summary: SpaceX has acquired wireless spectrum licenses from EchoStar for $17 billion, enabling Boost Mobile subscribers to access Starlink's direct-to-cell service. This move is part of SpaceX's plan to develop the next generation of its cellular satellite service. Following the announcement, EchoStar's stock surged into record territory.

title: Thousands Rally Across Brazil Amid Bolsonaro Trial Countdown
snippets: The ex-president is accused of trying to overturn his election loss but his supporters say it is a witch hunt.

Thousands gathered to show their support for Jair Bolsonaro in the cities of Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Porto Alegre and Brasilia. The former Brazilian president is accused of trying to overturn the 2022 election result.
Tensions are heating up in Brazil as the nation enters the final week of former President Jair Bolsonaro’s trial on attempted coup charges.
titles: How the coup trial of Jair Bolsonaro has divided Brazil
Brazil: Bolsonaro backers rally ahead of coup trial verdict
Brazilians Protest as Bolsonaro Coup Trial Nears Verdict
summary: Thousands rallied in Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Porto Alegre, and Brasilia, both supporting and opposing former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, as his trial for attempting to overturn the 2022 election result approaches its final week.

title: South Korea to Repatriate 300 Workers Detained in ICE Raid at Hyundai-LG in Geor
snippets: South Korea arranged for workers detained in an immigration raid in Georgia to be released and flown home. Foreign Minister Cho Hyun is flying in the opposite direction to deal with the political and economic fallout.
South Korea said it intends to repatriate the more than 300 of its nationals who were detained during an immigration raid on a Hyundai factory in Georgia.
South Korea says it has a deal for release of those caught in Hyundai Georgia raid.
titles: South Korea minister heads to US following Hyundai ICE raid
South Korea announces deal to repatriate workers detained in Hyundai raid
South Korea, irked at U.S. raid at Hyundai plant, announces deal for detainees' release
summary: Over 300 South Korean workers were detained in the largest ICE raid of Trump's administration at a Hyundai-LG site in Georgia. South Korea announced plans to repatriate the workers, stating a charter plane will be sent to the U.S. once administrative procedures are completed. The South Korean government's action follows the significant immigration enforcement operation, highlighting its commitment to assisting its nationals abroad.

title: Quebec Aluminum Sector to Get Major Boost from $5B Fund Against US Tariffs
snippets: Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry Mélanie Joly says the Quebec aluminum sector will receive "hundreds of millions of dollars" in funding as a result of tariff impacts.

Industry Minister Mélanie Joly says Quebec’s aluminum sector is likely to receive “hundreds of millions of dollars” from a $5 billion fund to help sectors slammed by U.S. tariffs. Nearly all of Canada’s aluminum is produced in Quebec. Joly says the federal government hasn&#82
titles: Joly expects aluminum sector to receive ‘hundreds of millions’ in tariff relief
Joly expects aluminum sector to receive ‘hundreds of millions’ in tariff relief
summary: Industry Minister Mélanie Joly announced that Quebec's aluminum sector will receive "hundreds of millions of dollars" in support from a $5 billion fund designed to aid industries affected by U.S. tariffs. This funding aims to mitigate the impact of these tariffs, with Quebec being a major producer of aluminum in Canada.

title: Great North Run Apologizes for Incorrect Sunderland Image on Medals

  • When maps go wrong: from the Great North R
Great North Run organisers have issued an apology, saying "Wear sorry!" after medals awarded to finishers of Sunday's event featured the incorrect city and river.

summary: Organisers of the Great North Run apologized for mistakenly featuring Sunderland's image and the River Wear on the event's medals and finisher T-shirts, describing them as the "most unique" in the event's history. This error has no direct connection to the actual location of the run.

title: Uber to Test Driverless Cars in Germany Next Year with Momenta
snippets: Uber and one of its many robotaxi partners, Momenta, will test fully driverless cars in Germany next year. The news comes as Europe continues to lag behind the US and China in the number of commercially operational robotaxi services. The companies say they will test Level 4 autonomous vehicles in Mu

Momenta is one of 20 global AV partners that Uber has scooped up across its ridehail, delivery, and freight businesses. Uber says those partnerships have already generated an annualized rate of 1.5 million mobility and delivery.
titles: Uber and Momenta will test fully driverless cars in Germany
Uber and Momenta to test autonomous vehicles in Germany in 2026
summary: Uber, in partnership with Momenta, plans to test fully driverless, Level 4 autonomous vehicles in Germany next year, marking a step towards catching up with the US and China in commercial robotaxi services. This initiative is part of Uber's broader strategy, involving 20 global AV partners, aimed at enhancing its ride-hail, delivery, and freight services, which have already achieved an annualized rate of 1.5 million mobility and delivery operations.

title: Visible Time Crystal Created; CRISPR Efficiency Tripled
snippets: Physicists at the University of Colorado Boulder have created the first time crystal that humans can actually see, using liquid crystals that swirl into never-ending patterns when illuminated by light. This breakthrough builds on Nobel laureate Frank Wilczek’s 2012 theory of time crystals—structures

Northwestern scientists have developed a new nanostructure that supercharges CRISPR’s ability to safely and efficiently enter cells, potentially unlocking its full power to treat genetic diseases. By wrapping CRISPR’s tools in spherical DNA-coated nanoparticles, researchers tripled gene-editing succ
titles: Scientists just made the first time crystal you can see
Scientists just made CRISPR three times more effective
summary: Physicists at the University of Colorado Boulder have developed the first visible time crystal, which forms endless patterns in liquid crystals under light, advancing Frank Wilczek's 2012 theory. Concurrently, Northwestern scientists have enhanced CRISPR's efficiency and safety in gene editing by encapsulating its components in DNA-coated nanoparticles, tripling its success rate. These innovations mark significant advancements in physics and genetic engineering.
